article_title: Tax on high-cost health plans opposed
article_text:
Tax on high-cost health plans opposed

Photo: Leah Nash /New York Times Kurt Gallow, president of the local unit of the Association of...

At the paper mill in Longview, Washington, Kurt Gallow and his wife, Brenda, are worrying about his company’s proposed new health care plan, which would require workers to pay as much as $6,000 toward their families’ medical bills.

article_metadata.author.name: By Reed Abelson, New York Times

og.description:
At the paper mill in Longview, Washington, Kurt Gallow and his wife, Brenda, are worrying about his company's proposed new health care plan, which would require workers to pay as much as $6,000 toward their families' medical bills.

Brenda Gallow's diabetic condition almost certainly will mean thousands of dollars more a year for her care alone, if the new plan is put in place, which may happen as early as next year.

"Some of the people with health problems will definitely pay more," said Gallow, who is president of the local unit of the Association of Western Pulp & Paper Workers.

The union is in heated negotiations with the mill's owner, KapStone Paper and Packaging, over benefits, among other issues.
